(Singing) If I only was a fool, I'll be loving...
That was Nigel Gault of Global Insight, John Silvia from Wachovia, and John Challenger of the staffing firm Challenger, Gray & Christmas.
Analysts thought the economy would grow by about 110,000 jobs in August.
Instead, it went in the other direction, losing 4,000 jobs.
The stock market wasn't happy.
The Dow Jones was down sharply this afternoon.
People blamed the declining jobs on the housing slump and the tightened credit market.
Nigel Gault said businesses seem wary about adding more workers at an uncertain time.

If firms look around and see the headlights about slowing growth, tighter financial conditions, the natural response is to become more cautious in your hiring, just in case it turns out that it's, you know, a worst-case outcome for the economy, you don't want to be caught with too much stuff on hand.
The construction and manufacturing sectors posted some of the biggest losses.
Companies in the mortgage-lending sector have announced huge layoffs well, but most of them didn't show up in today's report.
In fact, this afternoon, the lender Countrywide said it would cut up to 12,000 jobs over the next several months.
The company expects its business to drop by a quarter next year.
In a letter, Countrywide CEO Angelo Mozilo called the current environment, quote, ""the most severe in contemporary history of our industry.
Nigel Gault said next month's report will begin to show the real impact of the subprime mortgage meltdown.
We've got to expect that September number is going to be worse.
The losses will likely end up in the tens of thousands.
Like many other analysts, Gault called on the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates to help businesses and homeowners.
So there will be some people who with lower interest rates will be able to make their payments.
And also, it encourages banks to lend.
It encourages people to borrow.
I mean, we have to be realistic about it.
Lower interest rates are not going to stop the slowdown in the economy.
It's a question of trying to mitigate the damage.
Most analysts expect the fed will cut rates by at least a quarter of a percentage point at its next meeting, September 18th.
So what are the chances of recession?
Wachovia's John Silvia thinks it's still unlikely, but he worries about more jolts.

Given this kind of background when we talk about slower job growth and therefore slower consumer income growth, it doesn't take much for another shock to come along perhaps oil prices to really move us into recessionary scenario.
At least one analyst was hopeful.
Jim Glassman is a senior economist with the J.P.
Morgan Chase.
He said the jobs report showed a bigger loss in government employment than probably occurred.
He expected that sector to snap back this month and help the overall job picture for September.
We could see a payroll number that's up 50,000 or 100,000.
There was one positive number in today's report, unemployment remains steady at 4.6 percent.
But economists said that wasn't because people were finding lots of work, instead, it was because hundreds of thousands had stopped looking.
Frank Langfitt, NPR News, Washington.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Melissa Block.
And I'm Michele Norris.
For the first time today, the U.S.
military accused Iranian intelligence of providing weapons and support to Sunni insurgents in Iraq.
Several times over the past few months, the U.S.
has accused Iran of smuggling weapons into Iraq, mostly for the use of Shiite militias.
Iran is a Shiite Muslim nation, and its support for the Shiite political forces is long-standing.
But today, the U.S.
military displayed Iranian weapons it seized this week, weapons the military says apparently were destined for the enemies of Iran's Shiite allies in Iraq.
NPR's Mike Shuster has more details.
There have been some recent hints from U.S.
military officials that Iranian weapons were finding their way into Sunni hands.
But today, Major General William Caldwell put the charge on the record.
We have, in fact, found some cases recently where Iranian intelligence services have provided to some Sunni insurgent groups some support.
Caldwell, who is spokesman for the U.S.
military in Iraq, pointed to the seizure of weapons on Monday in the jihad neighborhood of southwest Baghdad, a Sunni neighborhood.
Caldwell said a tip from a local resident led to a specific house nearby.
They found a black Mercedes sedan in the front of the home.
On the backseat was a recently manufactured Iranian rocket.
They opened the trunk.
Inside, they found some recently manufactured weapons from Iran.
They found more weapons from Iran as they went through the house and through the backyard.
Today, the U.S.
military puts some of those weapons on display, including mortar rounds and the 107-millimeter rocket from the backseat of the Mercedes.
Major Marty Webber, a weapons expert, said the markings on the weapons, plus their shape, all point to Iran as their source.
The unique and significant thing about the stuff that we're seeing now with their Iranian signatures is the year of manufacture.
The lot numbers that show in 2005 and 2006, that is stuff that was not here prior when you had Shia insurgent groups who were fighting, you know, the Saddam regime.
This is the stuff that has been coming to this country since coalition forces have, you know, come in and liberated Iraq.
The U.S.
military did not explicitly say the weapons it displayed today were intended for Sunni insurgents, but that was the implicit message.
Nor did Caldwell offer an explanation why Iranian intelligence would provide weapons to Sunni insurgents who could very well use them against Shiite militias or civilians.
He also did not address the possibility that these weapons could have been purchased on the black market.
Just a few days after, President Obama met with executives of the country's biggest credit card companies.
We want to preserve the credit card market, but we also want to do so in a way that eliminates some of the abuses and some of the problems that a lot of people are familiar with.
NPR's Rebecca Hersher is covering the conference in Poland.
Hi there, Rebecca.
The idea that the label is set in stone for all time misunderstands the way the process works.
When the FDA approves a drug and its label, it does so based on small clinical trials, one or two thousand people.

When the drug is marketed and goes to lots and lots of people and the adverse reactions start occurring in greater numbers, the regulations permit a drug maker to supplement the label with that information.
So your case depends on us finding that there was a new risk here that the FDA did not consider?
The question is what did the manufacturer know and when did it know it.
The manufacturer has a duty of due care, a duty to analyze new information on risk, and to make appropriate changes in the warning to reflect that.
It didn't live up to that duty.
Nina Totenberg, NPR News, Washington.
architect Jean Nouvel's new branch of the Louvre Museum, now under construction in Abu Dhabi, is expected to cost around $108 million.

The plans call for pools of crystal clear water lapping against walls of pearl white perfection; rectangular islands surround the main building, and above it, a latticed canopy allows intermittent shafts of light to stream down onto the museum's walls.
Jean Nouvel has just been named the winner of this year's Pritzker architecture prize.
The Pritzker is often called the Nobel of architecture.
Jean Nouvel has more than 200 buildings around the world, as Edward Lifson reports.
Jean Nouvel's buildings provoke many moods.
He does this by moving the visitor through darkness, through manipulated light and rich colors.

He can confront you with graphic images, images of history, as at his Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis, where ghostly figures from Shakespeare and from the Guthrie's past appear, in the right light, on the wall.
At his Cartier Foundation for Contemporary Art in Paris you look through wall after wall of highly transparent glass until your eye finds the back yard.
In it soars an historic 200-year-old cedar tree.
Nouvel's building nearly disappears.
Reflections of tree and sky remain.
He tries to link to the past, much like his countryman Marcel Proust.
Jean Nouvel says when he gets a commission, he surveys the site, learns what was there, what is there, how it was used, how it will be used and he tries to provide links.
I think when you are an architect you have to work with the differences of the climates, of the visitation, of the color of the rock, of the sky and so on.
And not always the same things.
You have to invent small worlds.
You have to invent surprises.
His approach to architecture was born in the radicalism of 1968 Paris.
Now 62 years old, Jean Nouvel wears a lot of black, shaves his head, and he looks oddly like Dr. Evil from the ""Austin Powers"" flicks.
He even made noise about wanting to be a filmmaker.
Jean-Louis Cohen teaches architecture history at New York University.
He says Nouvel's designs incorporate ideas from film, photography and other contemporary arts.
This is probably the reason why his architecture has taken new qualities.
Because his designs are emerged in a much broader visual culture than the designs of many of his contemporaries.
